In GitLab by @sigmavirus24 on Nov 8, 2016, 20:01

>  I don't think this is a correct behaviour, as in my opinion, it supposed to record a snapshot of current code state.

This was not what this was documented as being the purpose.

> in any case, why would I worry what flake8 issues were previously recorded?

Given that Flake8 redirects all output (including logs) to the log file, it makes more sense to make this append by default. For users and developers, debugging is easier when comparing subsequent runs.

> That change to append mode actually has broken our CI. We were using --output-file option to produce a snapshot of commit and then checking if there were any errors, but now it always reports the same error

In my opinion, your CI shouldn't be keeping these files around near where you check for success or failure. They should be saved as artifacts for reference but then cleared after each run. Regardless, why would you not use Flake8's exit code to check if there were errors?

>>>

This was not what this was documented as being the purpose.
>>>

It doesn't look like purpose is being documented... at least I couldn't find it other than "your tool for style guide enforcement".

> Given that Flake8 redirects all output (including logs) to the log file, it makes more sense to make this append by default. For users and developers, debugging is easier when comparing subsequent runs.

Where can I read about this? From observation, I only noticed that everything is being printed to stdout and nothing to a log file. If you mean by adding an option to output to a file, then yes, but I wouldn't call that a log file, just a snapshot of codebase state. And generally there are no log messages if there are no errors.

> In my opinion, your CI shouldn't be keeping these files around near where you check for success or failure. They should be saved as artifacts for reference but then cleared after each run. Regardless, why would you not use Flake8's exit code to check if there were errors?

With this, you sort of agree, that output file should be cleared, though it is my interpretation of your message. After speaking around with fellow developers, they all agreed that that output file should be overwritten, but maybe it is just in my environment. And we are using the status of flake8 exit code, but we also convert the output with flake8-junit-report, which fails if there are some flake8 errors in the output file.

In any case, if you feel that the current behaviour is the right one, close this ticket. I've already added a step in my CI to remove the output file before making a new one, and I'm not going to agree that flake8 is a logging tool how your codebase evolved (VCS is doing that).

In GitLab by @sigmavirus24 on Nov 9, 2016, 13:01

> It doesn't look like purpose is being documented... at least I couldn't find it other than "your tool for style guide enforcement".

Are you talking about the purpose of `--output-file` or the purpose of `flake8`.

> Where can I read about this? From observation, I only noticed that everything is being printed to stdout and nothing to a log file. 

If you increase the verbosity of flake8, e.g., `flake8 -vv --output-file=my-output-file.txt .` then you get log messages in there. You also get the standard output included with those log messages. Further if you do, `flake8 -vv --show-source --output-file=my-output-file.txt .` you get yet more information in the output file. `--output-file` is literally the catch-all for all output.

> With this, you sort of agree, that output file should be cleared

You want them cleared, so I'm telling you that you should clear them, by removing the file. Given that the exact behaviour of `--output-file` was never documented, it's saddening that your coworkers feel it should not append as someone who has interacted with parameters for that deal with logfiles would expect it to.

issue.body:
In GitLab by @thibaultdelor on Oct 22, 2018, 24:31

I work on a very large codebase and I would like to enable/disable some rules for an entire folder (and it's subfolder).

One of the common use case I have is that I want to disable docstring checks for my test folder.

Running flake8 several times for each folder is not an acceptable solution for both user-friendliness reason and IDE compatibility.

I haven't looked at flake8 codebase but I guess it would possible to implement a mechanism that looks for `.flake8` file in all the folders the linter go through and this configuration file would override the ignore/excludes rules for this specific folder (and subfolder).

If that's something that flake8 maintainers are not against, I could try to implement it and raise a MR.

issue.title: Recursively update configuration as we traverse subdirectories

repository.name: flake8
repository.description: flake8 is a python tool that glues together pycodestyle, pyflakes, mccabe, and third-party plugins to check the style and quality of some python code.

issue.body:
In GitLab by @ahal on Jun 3, 2016, 09:16

This is a pretty big change, but maybe something to consider either for 3.0 or post 3.0. Currently (both 2.x and 3.0a) finalize the configuration at the start, and then apply that same configuration to every file that gets linted. I think it makes more sense to instead scan for configuration at each directory as we go along.

So starting at the project root (or cwd):
1. Load configuation in directory (overriding any existing config)
2. Lint files in directory
3. Move to included subdirectory
4. Go back to 1

This allows you to have a global project configuration, but also allow sub-directories within that project to set their own rules.
